passages.text: Tariff Talks; Lowering PT \(\) 505\$

Yesterday, CAT announced that it expects a higher impact from the latest tariff announcements since the 2Q call, with an updated headwind of \(\) 500- 600M\(up from\) \ \(400 - 500MM\) previously) in 3Q and a full year impact of \(\) 1.5 - 1.8B\(up from\) \ \(1.3 - 1.5B\) previously). As a result, it now expects its operating margin to be in the bottom half of its target range. Note that its expectations for revenues remain unchanged. We are lowering our estimates with 2025/26 EPS now at\) \ \(18.13\) and \(\) 20.00\(, respectively. Our Dec 25 PT is now lower by\) \ \(15\) to \(\) 505\$ based on \(\sim 25x\) FY1 PE. We rate CAT Overweight. The latest tariff guidelines, especially regarding the value of steel and aluminum in a broad range of imported components and finished products, are not an idiosyncratic risk to CAT and will impact most industrial companies in our coverage that have a global supply chain. The long- term impact on sales, market share, and margins remains to be seen based on what the 'new normal' will look like in terms of reciprocal tariffs, who has pricing power, and who will be able to flex their global supply chain. We caught up with management today and below are the key highlights.

What's new since the 2Q earnings call? On August \(19^{\mathrm{th}}\) , the Department of Commerce issued new guidance based on Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962 (Section 232) that will apply to the steel and aluminum content in a broad range of components and products. A \(50\%\) tariff rate will now be applied to the value of steel and aluminum in those categories. This is accountable for the vast majority of the up- sized tariff headwind announced by CAT yesterday. Large machinery, including excavators and combines, will now be assessed based on the value of the steel and aluminum content within them and be tariffed at \(50\%\) , while the non- steel or non- aluminum content will face the existing reciprocal tariffs for the specific country of origin. In simple terms, there will now be layers of tariffs when a product or component is imported into the US. Furthermore, reciprocal tariffs on imports from India also went up to \(50\%\) , which is also embedded in the updated guide from CAT.

How is CAT planning to mitigate these tariff costs? All options are on the table for long- term mitigation. Near- term, mitigation actions have been limited' so Tar amid a fluid policy environment. Some levers, such as pricing, have long- term impacts and hence will be carefully evaluated before implementation. Our sense is that management is likely waiting for policy stability before implementing long- term changes, including list price increases and adjusting the supply chain.

What if Brazil retaliates? Based on media reports, Brazil is expected to announce retaliatory tariffs in response to the US's \(50\%\) tariff rate on imports from the country. This is something to keep an eye on, as several companies in our coverage, including CAT export into and out of Brazil.
CAT, CAT US Price (28 Aug 25): \(\) 434.91\$

We believe CAT's earnings power and FCF conversion continue to merit our Overweight rating and that standing estimates do not fully appreciate management's ability to drive margin improvement cycle- on- cycle. The company has been able to cut fixed costs by restructuring its Resource business, which should provide earnings upside as volumes push higher. CAT can be regarded as a net beneficiary of recent bouts of material cost inflation to the extent that its customers in mining and oil/gas are better off and looking to spend more on equipment. Additionally, we view CAT as the biggest winner of an extended US construction cycle.
Our Dec 2025 price target is \(\) 505\(based on \sim 25x FY1 PE, which we believe is still conservative as we expect multi - year \sim DD\%\) EPS growth to return in 2026.

We believe CAT's earnings power and FCF conversion continue to merit our Overweight rating and that standing estimates do not fully appreciate management's ability to drive margin improvement cycle- on- cycle. The company has been able to cut fixed costs by restructuring its Resource business, which should provide earnings upside as volumes push higher. CAT can be regarded as a net beneficiary of recent bouts of material cost inflation to the extent that its customers in mining and oil/gas are better off and looking to spend more on equipment. Additionally, we view CAT as the biggest winner of an extended US construction cycle.
Our Dec 2025 price target is \(\) 505\(based on \~25x FY1 PE, which we believe is still conservative as we expect multi - year \~DD\% EPS growth to return in 2026.\)

The chart(s) show J.P. Morgan's continuing coverage of the stocks; the current analysts may or may not have covered it over the entire period. J.P. Morgan ratings or designations: OW = Overweight, N = Neutral, UW = Underweight, NR = Not Rated

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex-Australia and ex-India) and U.K. small- and mid-cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. Morgan's Research website, https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.
